description: From Middle English deynen, from Old French deignier (“consider worthy”), from Latin dīgnō, dīgnārī (“consider worthy”), from dīgnus (“worthy”). Cognate to dignity and French daigner.

verbs.description: deign (third-person singular simple present deigns, present participle deigning, simple past and past participle deigned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To condescend; to do despite a perceived affront to one's dignity.
examples: He didn't even deign to give us a nod of the head; he thought us that far beneath him.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To condescend to give; to do something.
(obsolete) To esteem worthy; to consider worth notice.
